unnormalised: Subject: Air Quality: Breathing Easy (Or Not!)
normalised: Subject: Air Quality: Breathing Easy (Or Not!)

unnormalised: Let's talk about air quality. It’s something that affects all of us, especially here in India. I remember visiting my grandparents in Delhi back in 2010 – the air was noticeably different compared to my home in Bangalore. Now, it’s arguably even worse in some parts of the country.
normalised: Let's talk about air quality. It's something that affects all of us, especially here in India. I remember visiting my grandparents in Delhi back in two thousand and ten – the air was noticeably different compared to my home in Bangalore. Now, it's arguably even worse in some parts of the country.

unnormalised: Ever wonder why you cough more during Diwali (15/11/2023, last year was brutal!) or why your eyes water on your morning commute? The answer usually lies in the Air Quality Index (AQI). Higher the AQI, the worse it is.
normalised: Ever wonder why you cough more during Diwali (fifteenth November two thousand and twenty three, last year was brutal!) or why your eyes water on your morning commute? The answer usually lies in the Air Quality Index (A Q I). Higher the A Q I, the worse it is.

unnormalised: Factors like vehicular emissions (especially those old autorickshaws!), construction dust, industrial pollution (near places like Kanpur), and stubble burning in Punjab contribute significantly. Remember that time back in 2018, everyone was wearing masks even *before* COVID?
normalised: Factors like vehicular emissions (especially those old autorickshaws!), construction dust, industrial pollution (near places like Kanpur), and stubble burning in Punjab contribute significantly. Remember that time back in two thousand and eighteen, everyone was wearing masks even *before* C O V I D?

unnormalised: The impact on health is serious – respiratory problems, heart issues, and even cognitive decline. Kids are especially vulnerable. Places like IIT Delhi are doing some great research on innovative air purification technologies.
normalised: The impact on health is serious – respiratory problems, heart issues, and even cognitive decline. Kids are especially vulnerable. Places like I I T Delhi are doing some great research on innovative air purification technologies.

unnormalised: What can we do? Carpooling, using public transport (the Bangalore Metro is a blessing!), planting trees, and supporting policies that promote cleaner energy are all steps in the right direction. Even switching off your engine at traffic signals (it idles for ages, especially around peak hour at 09:00 hrs) makes a difference.
normalised: What can we do? Carpooling, using public transport (the Bangalore Metro is a blessing!), planting trees, and supporting policies that promote cleaner energy are all steps in the right direction. Even switching off your engine at traffic signals (it idles for ages, especially around peak hour at nine o'clock) makes a difference.
